tool_description: This Unofficial Medium API helps you get data from Medium (medium.com), quickly and reliably. You can gather data related to users, publications, articles, latestposts, top writers, etc...  Try our endpoints below! Visit our website, mediumapi.com, and feel free to email us at nishu@mediumapi.com for any query.
name: Medium
title: Medium

api_list.name: Get Article's Content
api_list.description:
Returns the content of a Medium Article in plain text, for the given `article_id`.

Note: This does not include text inside the image captions and embeds.
api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/article/562c5821b5f0/content"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
api_list.convert_code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/article/{article_id}/content"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())

api_list.name: Get Recommended Feed
api_list.description:
Returns a list of recommended articles (`article_ids`) for the given `tag`. This feed is similar to Topfeeds Trending Articles.

Using the `page` query string parameter, you can get the list page by page. The page number can be between 1 and 20. Each page will have up to 25 article IDs.

So at maximum, you can fetch 500 `article_ids` in 20 API calls.

api_list.name: Get Top Feeds
api_list.description:
Returns a list of `article_ids` (length <= 25) for the given `tag` and `mode`.

Mode:
- `hot` : For getting trending articles
- `new` : For getting latest articles
- `top_year` : For getting best articles of the year
- `top_month` : For getting best articles of the month
- `top_week` : For getting best articles of the week
- `top_all_time`: For getting best article of all time

required_parameters.name: mode
required_parameters.description:
-     `hot`: For getting trending articles
-     `new`: For getting the latest articles
-     `top_year`: For getting the best articles of the year
-     `top_month`: For getting the best articles of the month
-     `top_week`: For getting the best articles of the week
-     `top_all_time`: For getting the best article of all time

api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/topfeeds/data-science/new"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
api_list.convert_code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/topfeeds/{tag}/{mode}"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())

api_list.name: Get Article Info
api_list.description:
Returns article-related information such as

- Title
- Subtitle
- Author (ID)
- Tags
- Topics (assigned by Medium)
- Publication (ID)
- Published date and time
- Last Modified date and time
- Clap Count
- Voter Count
- Word Count
- Response Count
- Reading Time
- Language
- Unique Slug
- URL
- Image URL (Cover image)
- Top Highlight
- Whether the article is in a series or not (boolean)
- Whether the article is a shortform or not (boolean)
- Whether the article is locked or not (boolean)
api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/article/67fa62fc1971"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
api_list.convert_code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/article/{article_id}"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())

api_list.name: Get User Following
api_list.description:
Returns a list of users (`user_ids`) that the given user is following.

Use the `count` query parameter (_optional_) to limit the number of results. (count <= 1500)

**Note:** This list does not contain the `publication_ids` of the publications that the user is following. To get those, please use _Get User Publication Following_ endpoint (`/user/{user_id}/publication_following`).

api_list.name: Get User Info
api_list.description:
Returns user-related information such as their
- Username
- Full name
- Bio
- Followers count
- Following count
- Publication Following count
- Twitter Username
- Profile Image URL
- Background Image URL
- Logo Image URL
- Tipping Link
- List of tags in which the user is Top Writer
- When did the user become a Medium Member (conditional)
- Whether the user has Lists (boolean)
- Whether the user is a Medium-verified book author (boolean)
- Whether the user is enrolled in Medium Partner Program (boolean)
- Whether the user has allowed notes on their articles (boolean)
- Whether the user is suspended or not (boolean)


**Note:** If you don't know the `user_id`, you can get it from the Get User ID endpoint (**/user/id_for/{username}**).
api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/user/1985b61817c3"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
api_list.convert_code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/user/{user_id}"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())

api_list.name: Get User Followers
api_list.description:
Returns a list of followers (`user_ids`) for the given user. 

Use `count` query string parameter (optional) to limit the number of results. (count <= 25)

Use `after` query string parameter (optional) to get the results after a particular follower's user id.

**Note:**  When you get the response from the API, it will include an attribute called `next`. You can use this `next` attribute as query string parameter (`after`) when you make your next API request. This way, you can get the followers that come after the one you're currently looking at.

api_list.name: Get Related Articles
api_list.description:
Returns a list of the related articles (`article_ids`) for the given article (`article_id`).

**Note:** The length of the returned list will be equal to 4. These related posts will be from the same author, publication, or both.

api_list.name: Get Latest Posts
api_list.description:
Returns a list of latest "curated/distributed" posts (*article_ids*) for a topic/niche (as classified by the Medium platform). Example of a topic/niche can be: 
 - "blockchain" 
 - "relationships" 
 - "mental-health", etc ...

These are known as *topic-slugs*. At any given moment, this endpoint will return a list of 25 articles (*article_ids*).
api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/latestposts/blockchain"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
api_list.convert_code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/latestposts/{topic_slug}"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
            "X-RapidAPI-Host": "medium2.p.rapidapi.com"
        }

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())

api_list.name: Get Top Writers
api_list.description:
Returns a list of top writers (*user_ids*) within a particular topic/niche (e.g. "blockchain", "relationships", "artificial-intelligence").

**Note**: You can use `count` query string parameter to limit the number of results. The maximum number of top writers within a topic/niche will be 250.

api_list.name: Search Publications
api_list.description: Returns the list of *publication_ids* for the given search query results. (Max Length = 1000)

api_list.name: Search Lists
api_list.description: Returns an array of *list_ids* for the given search query results. (Max Length = 1000)

api_list.name: Search Users
api_list.description: Returns a list of *user_ids* for the given search query results. (Max Length = 1000)

api_list.name: Search Tags
api_list.description: Returns a list of *tags* for the given search query results. (Max Length = 1000)

api_list.name: Search Articles
api_list.description: Returns the list of *articles_ids* for the given search query results. (Max Length = 1000)

api_list.name: Get User Articles
api_list.description: Returns the list of articles (`articles_ids`) written by the given user.

api_list.name: Get Publication Articles
api_list.description:
Returns the list of `articles_ids`, of the latest 25 articles, posted in that publication.

Use the `from` query parameter to get the articles before that date and time.

api_list.name: Get Publication Newsletter
api_list.description: Returns information related to the associated newsletter for the given publication. This includes their subscriber's count, name, description, unique id, etc...
api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://medium2.p.rapidapi.com/publication/98111c9905da/newsletter"

headers = {
            "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",

api_list.name: Get Publication Info
api_list.description:
Returns the publication related information such as Publication name, Tagline, Description, Tags, Followers Count, Twitter username, Instagram username, Facebook Page name, etc ...

**Note**: If you don't know the *publication_id*, you can get it from any article published by it. Use endpoint "/article/{article_id}" to retrieve the *publication_id*.
